comment: As a result of this interchange, white has 3 pawn islands, black has 2. A pawn island is a group of pawns separated by open files. This should give black a slight endgame advantage. The reason that fewer pawn islands is better, is that they don't need pieces to defend them (they can defend each other).
reasoning: This comment correctly explains the mistake made by the player because it highlights the importance of pawn islands in the endgame and points out that fewer pawn islands (owned by black in this case) could potentially give black a slight advantage.
moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2
context: This is a game between W17 (as White) and B17 (as Black). Last move played: Black plays Bishop takes on d2
reformulated: After Black's last move of Bishop taking on d2, they've left White with 3 pawn islands while Black has just 2. This means Black has a slight edge in the endgame because pawn islands don't need their own pieces to defend; they can help each other. This move by Black could be seen as strategically sound because it simplifies the position without giving away anything significant to White.

comment: Remember your heavy pieces (Queen, rooks) want to double on the open file (column). Therefore, Qb8 would be quite strong, to establish b-file control. Black could follow-up with ...Qb7 (pressuring white's e-pawn), ...Rfb8, and/or Rb1 with a definite edge for black.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake made by the player because it identifies the strategic opportunity missed by not doubling the rooks on the open b-file, which would have given Black a significant advantage.

reasoning: The comment explains that the move Qa8 not only puts pressure on the e-pawn but also leads to a sequence of threats that force white into a defensive position, ultimately resulting in a tactical advantage for black.
